messages.content:
You are an expert software engineer specialized in bug localization. 
Your task is to identify the files most likely to contain bugs based on bug descriptions. 
You have access to several tools to help you in this task. 
From the files you have seen, you will select 1 files that you believe are most likely to contain the bug.

<bug_description>
Migrations uses value of enum object instead of its name.
Description
	 
		(last modified by oasl)
	 
When using Enum object as a default value for a CharField, the generated migration file uses the value of the Enum object instead of the its name. This causes a problem when using Django translation on the value of the Enum object. 
The problem is that, when the Enum object value get translated to the users language, the old migration files raise an error stating that the Enum does not have the corresponding value. (because the Enum value is translated to another language)
Example:
Let say we have this code in models.py:
from enum import Enum
from django.utils.translation import gettext_lazy as _
from django.db import models
class Status(Enum):
	GOOD = _('Good') # 'Good' will be translated
	BAD = _('Bad') # 'Bad' will be translated
	def __str__(self):
		return self.name
class Item(models.Model):
	status = models.CharField(default=Status.GOOD, max_length=128)
In the generated migration file, the code will be:
...
('status', models.CharField(default=Status('Good'), max_length=128))
...
After the translation, 'Good' will be translated to another word and it will not be part of the Status Enum class any more, so the migration file will raise the error on the previous line:
ValueError: 'Good' is not a valid Status
Shouldn't the code generated by the migration uses the name of the Status Enum 'GOOD', not the value of it, since it is changeable?
It should be:
('status', models.CharField(default=Status['GOOD'], max_length=128))
This will be correct regardless of the translated word
</bug_description>

The repository name is:
<repo_name>
django__django__e02f67ef2d03d48128e7a118bf75f0418e24e8ac
</repo_name>

You have access to the following tools:

* extract_relevant() -> Retrieve the most relevant info from the bug. Returns a JSON object with explanation, relevant code snippets, error messages and file paths mentioned in the bug. *

You must use these tools to find 1 files that are most likely to contain the bug. Start by analyzing the issue description and then decide which tool to use first.
If you are done, provide your final ranked list of 1 files most likely to contain bugs in a JSON array as follows: {"ranked_files": ["file1", "file2", ...]}
Otherwise, return only the tool call as JSON. Example: {"function_call": "func_name", "args": {"arg_name": 10} }
Reply ONLY with the JSON response.

Description
	(last modified by oasl)

The problem is that, when the Enum object value get translated to the users language, the old migration files raise an error stating that the Enum does not have the corresponding value. (because the Enum value is translated to another language)
Example:
Let say we have this code in models.py:

from django.db import models

	GOOD = _('Good') # 'Good' will be translated
	BAD = _('Bad') # 'Bad' will be translated
	def __str__(self):
		return self.name
class Item(models.Model):
	status = models.CharField(default=Status.GOOD, max_length=128)
In the generated migration file, the code will be:
...
('status', models.CharField(default=Status('Good'), max_length=128))
...
After the translation, 'Good' will be translated to another word and it will not be part of the Status Enum class any more, so the migration file will raise the error on the previous line:

It should be:
('status', models.CharField(default=Status['GOOD'], max_length=128))
This will be correct regardless of the translated word"
  }
}

tool_args.query: django migration enum default value CharField

query_preview:
The bug occurs when Django generates migration files for CharFields with Enum default values. Instead of using the enum name (e.g., 'GOOD'), it uses the enum value (e.g., 'Good' which may be translated), causing a ValueError when the translation changes the string value. models.py models.py Status Item status ValueError: 'Good' is not a valid Status class Status(Enum):
    GOOD = _('Good')
    BAD = _('Bad')

class Item(models.Model):
    status = models.CharField(default=Status.GOOD, max_length=128)

<args>
{'bug_description': "Migrations uses value of enum object instead of its name.
Description
	(last modified by oasl)

When using Enum object as a default value for a CharField, the generated migration file uses the value of the Enum object instead of the its name. This causes a problem when using Django translation on the value of the Enum object. 
The problem is that, when the Enum object value get translated to the users language, the old migration files raise an error stating that the Enum does not have the corresponding value. (because the Enum value is translated to another language)
Example:
Let say we have this code in models.py:
from enum import Enum
from django.utils.translation import gettext_lazy as _
from django.db import models
class Status(Enum):
	GOOD = _('Good') # 'Good' will be translated
	BAD = _('Bad') # 'Bad' will be translated
	def __str__(self):
		return self.name
class Item(models.Model):
	status = models.CharField(default=Status.GOOD, max_length=128)
In the generated migration file, the code will be:
...
('status', models.CharField(default=Status('Good'), max_length=128))
...
After the translation, 'Good' will be translated to another word and it will not be part of the Status Enum class any more, so the migration file will raise the error on the previous line:
ValueError: 'Good' is not a valid Status
Shouldn't the code generated by the migration uses the name of the Status Enum 'GOOD', not the value of it, since it is changeable?
It should be:
('status', models.CharField(default=Status['GOOD'], max_length=128))
This will be correct regardless of the translated word"}
</args>

	BAD = _('Bad') # 'Bad' will be translated

	status = models.CharField(default=Status.GOOD, max_length=128)
In the generated migration file, the code will be:
...
('status', models.CharField(default=Status('Good'), max_length=128))
...
After the translation, 'Good' will be translated to another word and it will not be part of the Status Enum class any more, so the migration file will raise the error on the previous line:
ValueError: 'Good' is not a valid Status
Shouldn't the code generated by the migration uses the name of the Status Enum 'GOOD', not the value of it, since it is changeable?
It should be:
('status', models.CharField(default=Status['GOOD'], max_length=128))
This will be correct regardless of the translated word"}

You are an expert software engineer specialized in bug localization. 
Your task is to review a ranked list of files most likely to contain bugs based on a bug description. 
You have access to the evidence seen during the investigation, such as file views and BM25 retrievals.
Your goal is to review and/or adjust the ranked list of files based on your confidence that each file contains the bug.

This is the bug description:
<bug_description>
Migrations uses value of enum object instead of its name.
Description
	 
		(last modified by oasl)
	 
When using Enum object as a default value for a CharField, the generated migration file uses the value of the Enum object instead of the its name. This causes a problem when using Django translation on the value of the Enum object. 
The problem is that, when the Enum object value get translated to the users language, the old migration files raise an error stating that the Enum does not have the corresponding value. (because the Enum value is translated to another language)
Example:
Let say we have this code in models.py:
from enum import Enum
from django.utils.translation import gettext_lazy as _
from django.db import models
class Status(Enum):
	GOOD = _('Good') # 'Good' will be translated
	BAD = _('Bad') # 'Bad' will be translated
	def __str__(self):
		return self.name
class Item(models.Model):
	status = models.CharField(default=Status.GOOD, max_length=128)
In the generated migration file, the code will be:
...
('status', models.CharField(default=Status('Good'), max_length=128))
...
After the translation, 'Good' will be translated to another word and it will not be part of the Status Enum class any more, so the migration file will raise the error on the previous line:
ValueError: 'Good' is not a valid Status
Shouldn't the code generated by the migration uses the name of the Status Enum 'GOOD', not the value of it, since it is changeable?
It should be:
('status', models.CharField(default=Status['GOOD'], max_length=128))
This will be correct regardless of the translated word
</bug_description>
